chapter.title: Installation
chapter.para: This chapter will give you instructions on how to install FLOW3, explain the difference between Distributions, Applications and Packages, show how to do basic database setup and where to check when things (seem to) go wrong.

section.title: Requirements
section.para: The following minimum requirements are operating system independent. Developers report working setups on Debian Linux, MacOS, Windows Vista and Windows 7 (Windows should support symbolic links, thus we will not actively support Windows XP).

listitem.para:
PHP 5.3.2 or newer
Modules: mbstring, pdo_*

Apache (recommended, what we use)
Apache modules: mod_rewrite
Apache configuration: AllowOverride FileInfo
IIS7 on Windows 7 with URL Rewrite has succesfully been tested as well
Cherokee under Mac OS 10.6 (Snow Leopard) is working fine

section.para: Other webservers could work, but have not been tested until now.

section.title: Quick Start: Install FLOW3 from a Release Archive
section.para: These steps require the server requirements to be set up. Instruction on how to do that can be found in the appendixes.

step.para: Download the FLOW3 Base Distribution from http://flow3.typo3.org/download/

Unpack it to the document root of the webserver (often "htdocs")
It is highly recommended to change the document root of the webserver to the Web subfolder of the FLOW3 distribution!

The webserver needs write permissions for some subfolders. The FLOW3 distribution provides a helper script for Unix like operating systems, which sets the permissions. Change to the top level folder of the FLOW3 distribution, from there you need to run the script setfilepermissions.sh. Execute this script providing the CLI user, webserver user and webserver group as parameters. On Debian Linux (Lenny) the commando would look like this:

section.para: Now you can check if FLOW3 works by pointing your browser to http://<hostname>/ . If everything works you should see the welcome screen of the FLOW3 distribution (this may take some time on the first call, because FLOW3 needs to initialize itself and to create caching data): The FLOW3 welcome screen

tip.para: On Windows systems PHP causes problems with long filenames. To avoid errors you should change the configuration of the cache to a place that leads to a very short absolute filepath, for example C:\temp\. Do that by adjusting the following line of the file Configuration/Settings.yaml in your FLOW3-Distribution: temporaryDirectoryBase: C:/temp/Your best bet is to use the Settings.yaml.example file distributed with FLOW3 and copy it to Settings.yaml before starting from scratch.

section.title: Basic database setup
section.para: Until now FLOW3 has no database connection configured, thus it would not be possible to persist objects. Here are the very basics on how to configure the Doctrine 2 ORM FLOW3 uses by default. More information on configuring the persistence layer of FLOW3 is available in the corresponding chapter later in this manual.

step.para: Create a database you will use with FLOW3
Open Configuration/Settings.yaml and fill in the missing pieces of information.

para.literallayout: FLOW3: persistence: backendOptions: driver: 'pdo_mysql' # adjust to your database type dbname: 'flow3' # adjust to your database name user: 'root' # adjust to your database user password: '' # adjust to your database password host: '127.0.0.1' # adjust to your database host path: '127.0.0.1' # adjust to your database host port: 3306 # adjust to your database port

tip.para: If you do not have a Configuration/Settings.yaml file, copy the Settings.yaml.example file distributed with FLOW3 to Settings.yaml before starting from scratch.

section.para: Now FLOW3 is ready to access your database, but you will need to tell it how your database needs to be "migrated" to have a table structure that matches your code. Information on this is available in the chapter on the persistence layer.
